html:
Is the G7X Mark III worth the upgrade, or is the Mark II still the champion of compact cameras? Let’s break it all down, shall we?

The Battle of the Compact Powerhouses

If you’ve ever ventured into the world of vlogging, researched anything at all about compact cameras, or just wanted a pocket-sized powerhouse, chances are you’ve come across the Canon G7X Mark II vs. Mark III conundrum. Rightly so these two cameras have been steady choices for folk in social media, jetsetters, and hobbyists.

Canon PowerShot G7X Mark II vs. Mark III:
A Quick Overview

First, let’s do a quick walk-through with this comparison table.

So, the Mark III is the clear winner, right? Well, not so fast! There’s a lot more to consider.

Design & Handling – Nearly Identical Twins

At first glance, the Canon G7X Mark II vs. III looks almost identical. Both cameras boast a solid metal build, a comfortable grip, and that famous flip-up screen that vloggers adore.

Key design similarities

  • Both have 3-inch tilting LCD touchscreens (perfect for selfies and vlogging).
  • They’re similar in size and weight, making them perfectly portable.
  • The button layout remains largely unchanged, so if you’re upgrading from Mark II to Mark III, it’s already familiar territory.

The Mark III sneaks in a microphone jack, a feature many Mark II users begged for. If you’re serious about better audio quality for vlogging, this alone might sway you.

Image Quality – Same Sensor, Different Processing

When it comes to image quality, is there a major difference between Canon G7X Mark II and III?

Both cameras pack the same 20.1MP 1-inch sensor, but the Mark III has an upgraded DIGIC 8 processor (compared to the Mark II’s DIGIC 7).

What does this mean in the real world?

  • Better low-light performance: The Mark III handles noise slightly better in darker conditions.
  • Faster processing speed: The Mark III can capture 20fps burst shooting (vs. 8fps on the Mark II).
  • No drastic change in photo quality: If you’re primarily shooting stills, the difference isn’t mind-blowing.

For photography alone, the Canon G7X Mark II vs. III debate isn’t as dramatic—the improvements are minor.

Video Capabilities – Where the Mark III Shines

Now, if video is your priority, the G7X Mark III vs. Mark II battle has a clear winner.

4K Video & Slow-Mo Fun

  • The Mark II maxes out at 1080p 60fps.
  • The Mark III jumps to 4K at 30fps and 1080p at 120fps (for slow-motion shots).

Live Streaming & USB Charging – A Vlogger’s Dream

  • The Mark III allows direct live streaming to YouTube (huge for vloggers).
  • It also introduces USB-C charging, making it easier to charge on the go.

However, autofocus isn’t great on the Mark III for video. Many users report that the autofocus hunts more than a lost puppy.

So, if you’re buying a Canon G7X Mark III vs. Mark II for vlogging, it’s a trade-off:

  • Mark III offers better video quality and features but has autofocus issues.
  • Mark II has solid autofocus but lacks 4K and a mic jack.

Battery Life – Who Lasts Longer?

Neither of these cameras is known for stellar battery life, but the Canon G7X Mark II wins this round.

  • Mark II: ~265 shots per charge
  • Mark III: ~235 shots per charge

If you’re planning long shoots, carry extra batteries—especially with the Mark III.

Current Market Price & Service Life – Is the Canon PowerShot G7X Mark III Worth It?

At launch, the Canon PowerShot G7X Mark III was pricier, but prices have dropped. The Mark II remains the more affordable option. As of March 2025, the Canon G7X Mark ii is priced at approximately $599, while the G7X Mark iii is available for approximately $749. Prices may, of course, vary based on retailers and ongoing promotions.

Repair costs can do some serious damage to your pockets for both models. Say, for example, the Mark II has a repair cost of roughly $400. Canon has not officially announced the service life for either yet. The Mark II, released in 2016, has been on the market longer than the Mark III, which made its debut in 2019 and has a possibility of a service life until 2028, further suggesting that the prior may reach its end-of-service date sooner in comparison. 

Who Should Buy the Canon PowerShot G7X Mark II?

✅ You want a budget-friendly compact camera.
✅ You mainly shoot photos (not 4K video).
✅ You want better autofocus for casual video shooting.

Who Should Buy the Canon PowerShot G7X Mark III?

✅ You need 4K video and live streaming.
✅ You want USB charging and a mic input.
✅ You’re okay with manual focus workarounds for video.

Conclusion – Which One Wins?

So, in the Canon PowerShot G7X Mark II vs. Mark III showdown, which is better?

  • If you’re a vlogger or video-first creator, the Mark III is the way to go—despite its autofocus quirks.
  • If you’re a casual photographer or budget-conscious buyer, the Mark II still holds up extremely well.

Ultimately, the Canon G7X Mark II vs. III debate comes down to your needs. Do you need 4K and better video features, or is the tried-and-true Mark II enough?

Either way, you’re getting one of the best compact cameras Canon has ever made. Now go out and shoot some amazing content!

FAQs

Is the Canon PowerShot G7X Mark III worth the upgrade from the Mark II?

If you shoot a video, yes. If you’re mainly taking photos, not necessarily.

Does the Canon PowerShot G7X Mark III have better autofocus than the Mark II?

For photos, it’s similar. For video, the Mark II’s autofocus is actually more reliable.

Is the Canon PowerShot G7X Mark III good for vlogging?

Yes, but only if you’re willing to deal with some autofocus quirks. The mic jack, 4K, and live streaming make it a solid choice.
